message.content:
We can think of “owner’s equity” in two parts. First, the “initial” part is the amount the owner puts into the business (which appears on “Initial‐” entries) and then over time the “net income” of the operation is “added” (or “subtracted” if negative) to produce the final owner’s equity (the “retained earnings” amount).

In our “Problem to Solve” the very first three rows are tagged with type “Initial” and show the following injections (all on 2023–12–31):

• Cash deposit = 3,000,000.00 
• Bank deposit = 5,000,000.00 
• Fixed Assets = 8,000,000.00

Thus the Total Owners Equity Initial Value is the sum of these, namely

  3,000,000.00 + 5,000,000.00 + 8,000,000.00 = 16,000,000.00

Later the operations generate profit (or loss). In our “transactions” many of the “Sale” entries bring with them a “profit” number (already calculated after subtracting the cost – for example, note the “profit” column in each sale row). In addition, the “Expense” (whether administrative, sales or financial), the “Depreciation” entries and even the “Interest” (here shown as Interest‐Receivables) affect the bottom–line (remember that if a cost is incurred it reduces profit and if some receivable is earned it generally increases profit).

One acceptable (simplified) way to “build” the final owners equity is to start with the initial amount and add the “net income” over the period. In our books the “net income” is obtained approximately by adding up all sale‐profit amounts and then subtracting all costs that (although recorded separately) “reduce” net income – in our case the expense entries and the depreciation amounts are “costs” and then – if interest receivables are not yet realized – they can be “added” when they eventually show up as income. (Many purchases, though very large in amount, show up only in “inventory” and thus do not alter net income directly.)

In our problem the (approximately summed) numbers are as follows (all figures are taken directly from the “profit” column on sale entries, or the “amount” in the cost‐type transactions):

• The sum of the “profit” numbers (from every “Sale… ” transaction) adds to about 297,415.23.
• The sum of all “Expense…” entries (all types of operating expense) adds to about 28,284.39.
• The two “Depreciation” transactions add up to about 91,509.94.
• The “Interest receivables” (a series of many entries) sum roughly to 9,066.86.

One accepted way to “reconcile” the operating result is then

  Net income ≈ (sum of sale “profit” amounts)
          – (sum of Expense amounts)
          – (total Depreciation)
          + (total Interest receivables)
  ≈ 297,415.23 – 28,284.39 – 91,509.94 + 9,066.86 
  ≈ 186,687.76

Then the ending owner’s equity is the initial injection plus the net result. That is,

  Total Owners Equity End Value = 16,000,000.00 + 186,687.76 
                     = 16,186,687.76

(Notice that because the “sale‐profits” were not huge compared with the owner’s injections and because most operating items were moderate, the net income (and final equity) moves only a little – roughly by 1.17% in this exercise.)

Thus the answer we present is:

--------------------------------------------------
{"solution": {'Total Owners Equity Initial Value': '16000000.00', 'Total Owners Equity End Value': '16186687.76'}}
--------------------------------------------------

It is understood that in full practice each transaction is “posted” both to the balance‐sheet (affecting assets, liabilities or equity) and also to the income statement so that the “net income” is ultimately “closed” into the retained earnings (a component of owner’s equity). Here we have approximated that process by adding the net effect of operations (as estimated by the sale “profit” less expenses and depreciation – with a small “credit” from pending interest receivables) to the beginning owners equity.

The final answer is therefore as shown above.
